Award.AwardTitle: Summer Workshop Series in Macroeconomic Theory and Dynamic Modeling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a series of workshops that will be hosted by the University of Minnesota in collaboration with the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. The workshops bring together junior and senior researchers to concentrate on theoretical issues in macroeconomics and dynamic economic modeling. Young researchers use the workshops as an opportunity to get feedback on preliminary research and also form new collaborations. The research presented focuses on fundamental questions facing macroeconomic policy makers, including the design of the tax system, monetary policy, and the role of social insurance.

Each summer's topics are chosen by an organizing committee coordinated by the Principal Investigators. Topics may include debt and international lending, heterogeneity and inequality, labor market behavior, health and social insurance, financial markets, technology and firm dynamics, development and financial inteagration, monetary policy, fiscal policy, long run growth, and macroeconomic consequences of contracting frictions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded a sequence of workshops hosted by the University of Minnesota during 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019. These workshops were part of the series of Summer Workshop in Macroeconomic Theory which began at Northwestern University in 1987 and have continued to take place annually in Minneapolis since 2000.  The workshops are organized around a program of formal seminars, and bring together researchers working directly in macroeconomic research encompassing both theoretical and empirical work. Topics of the workshops varied depending on the year, but include fiscal and monetary policy research, research on labor markets, market frictions and income inequality, research on productivity and economic growth, the study of global shocks and international trade, and the analysis of exchange rates and dollar safe assets among others. The workshops are attended by junior and senior researchers, both as presenters in the seminars as well as participants in the conference. The research presented in this conference series focuses on fundamental science that is relevant to many questions facing policy makers, including the appropriate use of monetary policy, the role of fiscal policy over the business cycle and fiscal solvency, the design of insurance mechanisms (including unemployment insurance), the impact of trade policy (trade agreement and trade wars) on the economy, and the design of redistributive policies in the presence of trends in inequality.
